text:
the more I think of it, the more parallelisms I can find between vi vs emacs and python vs julia:

Python/vi:

* already available in many Unix systems (but often an old version)
* effective to get quick tasks done
* many people don't know how to quit it, even if they want to

Julia/Emacs:

* development started at MIT
* startup can be horribly slow
* super extensible and composable
* many mind-blowing features/packages, hard to appreciate until you actually try them out

do you have anything to add?

elements.text:

text: I think you're missing "julia/emacs is obviously better than python/vi"

elements.text: I think you're missing "julia/emacs is obviously better than python/vi"

text: but your comparison is indeed interesting. The MIT thing is not completely coincidental, it's basically academia vs industry, both in terms of creators and aesthetics

elements.text: but your comparison is indeed interesting. The MIT thing is not completely coincidental, it's basically academia vs industry, both in terms of creators and aesthetics

text: interestingly both the creators of vim and python are dutch

elements.text: interestingly both the creators of vim and python are dutch

text: (ha! I added an emoji faster than you!)

elements.text: (ha! I added an emoji faster than you!)

text: instead I find it curious that Bill Joy (vi creator) and Guy L. Steele Jr (one of Emacs creators) worked together on Java at Sun at some point

elements.text: instead I find it curious that Bill Joy (vi creator) and Guy L. Steele Jr (one of Emacs creators) worked together on Java at Sun at some point

text: one more thing is that both julia and emacs have some lisp in it (both in actual code and in philosophy)

elements.text: one more thing is that both julia and emacs have some lisp in it (both in actual code and in philosophy)

text: oh, right, I wanted to mention that, thanks for reminding me!
